title: "Mommy and Daddy are getting married!" upright retro script
content:
I'm stumped.

Thanks

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Scan10001.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017114725/http:/typophile.com/files/Scan10001.JPG) | 103.25 KB |
author: samiam1973

comments.content:
It looks like a homemade font that resembles [Murray Hill](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017114725/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/murray-hill-sh/) done with a felt tip pen.

- Mike Yanega

Anyone???  
I thought it was one of the dinc typefaces....
That cap D reminds me of one of those CAC scripts.
Thanks. Where could I find those?

"CAC" was Create-A-Card, from American Greetings. According to [this site](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017114725/http:/greeting-card-software-review.toptenreviews.com/american-greetings-review.html), these kits may no longer be sold. I have a bunch of the CAC fonts in my Script Font ID Guide, but this apparently isn't one that I have.

- Mike Yanega

I did a search on 'CAC' with Fontseek and saw one called ['Pinafore'](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017114725/http:/www.dafont.com/font.php?file=cac_pinafore&page=1&nb_ppp_old=10&text=Dadd&nb_ppp=10&psize=m&classt=alpha)that resembled this at first glance, but it turns out to be more of a connected script.

The CAC idea might still be right, but my search didn't find it.

- Mike Yanega
I can't find anything either. I think the font which I was thinking of was really Nevison Casual. But that isn't a match. :^( Sorry.
Would it help if I added a larger sample (more characters)?

If this is from a greeting card, it's likely to be custom lettering. (Unusual product line, if it is :))

- Mike Yanega

It is. I got in contact with the publisher of the card.

thanks for all your help.

Back to the drawing board...
